jmash.MaltType.notes: Acid malt contains acids from natural lactic acids. Used by German brewers to adjust malt PH without chemicals to adhere to German purity laws. Also enhances the head retention.
High lactic acid. For lambics, sour mash beers, Irish stout, pilsners and wheats.
Amber colored dry malt extract, for general purpose use. Use in any medium to dark colored beer. Examples: Ales, Marzens, Amber Ale, India Pale Ale
Unhopped amber color liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any Ale. Examples: Amber ale, India Pale Ale, Munich style, Marzen, Bock
Roasted specialty malt used in some English browns, milds and old ales to add color and a biscuit taste. Intense flavor - so limit use. Low diastatic power so must be mashed with well modified malts.

Yields a slightly higher extract than Six Rox brewers Malt. Tends to give a smoother, less grainy flavored beer. Some brewers claim they can detect a significant difference in flavor. Lower protein and will yield a lower color than Six-Row Brewers Malt

Tends to increase lautering efficiency due to a stiffer husk. May be used as the base malt for any beer style. The enzymes in all varieties of the current crop are sufficient to support high percentages of specialty malts and adjuncts.
Provides color and sharp flavor in stouts and porters.
Adds a heavy roast flavor and dark color.
This malt is light in color with a sweet caramel flavor. It is a great malt for light lagers and ales.
Provides color, a unique flavor, body, and contribures to foam retention and beer stability. Gives a pronounced to sharp caramel flavor and a deep red color.
Provides color, body, and contributes to foam retention and beer stability. Gives a sweet, mild flavor and golden color without a significant flavor increase.
Provides color, body, and contributes to foam retention and beer stability. Gives a sweet, mild flavor and golden color.
Provides color, a unique flavor, body, and contributes to foam retention and beer stability. Gives a sweet, medium caramel flavor and a golden color to light red color.
Mild caramel, nutty flavor, sweet. adds color
Mild caramel, nutty flavor, sweet. adds color (Red Ale)
Mild caramel, nutty flavor, sweet. adds color (Red Ale)
Use in all types to adjust color and add nutty, toasted flavor. Chocolate flavor.
Munich Dunkels. Adds color/nutty flavor. Sometimes called Aromatic.
Provides a deep golden to brown color. Use in nut brown ales, IPAs and Scottish ales.
Increases malty flavor, provides balance. Use in Vienna, Maerzen and Oktoberfest.
Provides a very strong malt flavor and aroma to your beer.
Well modified, good attenuation.
Well modified, full flavour.
Malted wheat for use in Wheat beers.

Hulls are introduced to improve the speed of lautering when making high gravity or high adjunct beers. Hulls are neutral in flavor, body and color, and are inert Good for wheat beers, Wits, and others that have high protein mashes.
Adds significant body to Porters and Stouts. High haze producing protein prevents use in light beers.

Raw, unmalted barley can be used to add body to your beer. Use in homebrew requires very fine milling combined with a decoction or multi-stage mash. Performs best when used in small quantities with well modified grains.
Raw barley that has been "popped" open to open kernels Used in place of raw barley for faster conversion and higher yields. High in haze producing protein
Imparts a big malt aroma. Use in brown ales, Belgian dubbels and tripels.
Warm baked biscuit flavor and aroma. Increases body. Use in Belgian beers.
Significantly increases foam/head retention and body of the beer.
Caramel, full flavor, copper color. For Belgian ales, German smoked and bocks.
Belgian light crystal malt. Used in lighter Abbey or Trappist style ales.
Adds a nutty flavor, Brown Ales
Used to increase malt aroma and body with slightly more color.
Fully modified and is easily converted.
Pilsner style malted barley grain.
Malted wheat for use in Wheat beers.
Use for English ales, brown ales and porters. Adds a biscuit like flavor and aroma. Can be used as a substitute for toasted malt.
Dark color and dry roasted flavor characteristic of Stouts and Porters Use for: Coloring in small amounts, or flavoring of Stouts and Porters in larger amounts.

Unmalted barley roasted at high temperature to create a dry, coffee like flavor. Imparts a sharp acrid flavor characteristic of dry stouts. Gives "dryness" to a stout or porter -- much more so than regular Roasted Barley
Unmalted roasted grain, it is the backbone of many stouts. Imparts a sharp acrid flavor characteristic of dry stouts. Gives dryness to a stout or porter ,more so than regular Roasted Barley.
Dry, burnt, chalky character. Use in porters, stouts, brown ales and dark lagers.
Sweet caramel flavor, adds mouthfeel and head retention. For pale or amber ales.
Sweet caramel flavor, mouthfeel. For porters, stouts, old ales and any dark ale.
Imparts a dry, biscuit flavor. Used in nut brown ales, porters and some Belgian ales.
Imparts a rich sweet flavor. Used in Scottish ales, holiday ales and some old ales.
Imparts a rich sweet flavor. Used in Scottish ales, holiday ales and some old ales.
Dark German malt developed to add malt flavor of Alt, Marzen and Oktoberfest beers. Helps create authentic maltiness without having to do a decoction mash. Rarely available for homebrewers.
Requires multiple temperature mash. The same malt used by the original Budweiser brewery, Budweiser Budvar.
Crystalized Candi Sugar (Sucrose) used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales. Adds head retention and sweet aroma to beer. Darker variants also add color.
Crystalized Candi Sugar (Sucrose) used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales. Adds head retention and sweet aroma to beer. Darker variants also add color.
Crystalized Candi Sugar (Sucrose) used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales. Adds head retention and sweet aroma to beer. Darker variants also add color.
Common household baking sugar. Lightens flavor and body of beer. Can contribute a cider-like flavor to the beer if not cold-fermented or used in large quantities.
Significantly increases foam/head retention and body of the beer. Also sold under the names "Dextrine" and "Cara-Foam"
Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.
Very dark crystal malt - similar to a crystal 120 or Caramunich 120 malt. Adds strong caramel flavor, red color, and malty aroma.
Used to intensify aroma and color in dark, Munich beers and stouts.
Used to intensify aroma and color in dark, Munich beers and stouts.
Dark color and aroma - used in some German beers
Significantly increases foam/head retention and body of the beer. Also sold under the names "Dextrine" and "Cara-Pils (TM)"
Made from green malt. Imparts a light flavor, and slight red hue. Great for dark lagers and ales. Will contribute dextrins and add to foam stability. This grain may be steeped or mashed.
Caramel wheat malt - emphasizes wheat malt aroma and adds color to the beer. Popular for Dunkelweizens. Also known as Carawheat -- which is a registered trademark of Wyermann Malting.
For dark ales, hefeweizen, dunkelweizen, wheat bocks and double bocks.
Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.
Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.
Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.
Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.
Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.
Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.
Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt. Very Dark
Caramel, copper colored malt. Used in Belgian ales and German bocks.
Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.
Light Belgian crystal malt. Used in light Trappist and Abbey style Belgian ales.
Dark malt that gives a rich red or brown color and nutty flavor. Use for: Brown ales, porters, some stouts Maintains some malty flavor, not as dark as roasted malt.
Dark malt that gives a rich red or brown color and nutty flavor. Use for: Brown ales, porters, some stouts Maintains some malty flavor, not as dark as roasted malt.
Primarily used for color and aroma in top-fermented specialty beers.
Enhances aroma of dark ales and improves color. For dunkel rye wheat and ale.
Intensifies aroma and color in top-fermented beers such as dark wheat beers.
Intensifies aroma; improves color. For dark ales, alt, dark wheat, stout and porter.
Widely used for bottling at rate of approx 2/3 cup per 5 gallons of beer
Syrup derived from corn with many of the same properties as corn sugar. May be used to enhance gravity without adding much body or flavor. Limit percentage in batch to avoid wine/cider flavors.
Generally a neutral flavor, used to reduce maltiness of beer Produces beer with a milder, less malty flavor Uses: Primarily for light Bohemian and Pilsner lagers
Sweet, mild caramel flavor and a golden color. Use in light lagers and light ales.
Pronounced caramel flavor and a red color. For stouts, porters and black beers.
Sweet, mild caramel flavor and a golden color. Use in light lagers and light ales.
Sweet, mild caramel flavor and a golden color. Use in light lagers and light ales.
Sweet caramel flavor, deep golden to red color. For dark amber and brown ales.
Body and Richness. Distictive Nutty flavor and or sweet, smooth caramel flavor and a red to deep red color. For porters, old ales.
Body and Richness. Distictive Nutty flavor and or sweet, smooth caramel flavor and a red to deep red color. For porters, old ales.
Dark dry extract for general purpose use. Use as base or to increase gravity of any dark ale or lager.
Unhopped dark liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any dark beer. Examples: Porter, Brown ale, Bock, Oktoberfest, Stouts
Dark, unrefined brown sugar that contains molasses and other dark impurities. Great for brown ales and porters. Adds slight sweetness and smooth character.
In light-colored beers to give additional body. Adds richness without color.
All English Ales. Workhorse of British Brewing. Infusion Mash.
Pilsner base malt.
Roasted malt used in British milds, old ales, brown ales, nut brown ales.
Imparts a dry, biscuit flavor. Used in nut brown ales, porters and some Belgian ales.
Dark malt that gives a rich red or brown color and nutty flavor. Use for: Brown ales, porters, some stouts Maintains some malty flavor, not as dark as roasted malt.
Dry, nutty malty flavor. Promotes body. Use in English mild ales.
Light flavor, creamy head. For wheat beers, stouts, doppelbocks and alt beers.
Very light color dry malt extract for general purpose use. Use as base or to increase gravity of any ale or lager.
Enhances body and aroma. Stout, schwarzbier, brown ale, dark and amber ales.
For a desired malty, nutty flavor. Lagers, Oktoberfests and bock beer.
Earthy, rich smoke flavor
Increases malty flavor, provides balance. Use in Vienna, Marzen and Oktoberfest.
Dark malted wheat base for use in dark wheat styles such as Dunkleweizen.
Typical top fermented aroma, produces superb wheat beers.

Huskless oat crystal malt. Exotic ingredient for subtle nutty difference. This malt lends a sweet berry-nut flavor. Use at a rate of 4-15% of the total grist to deliver a deep golden hue with light caramel flavors as well as a creamy, satin finish.

An especially sweet and clean variety of barley which results in full and malty sweet beer. It has superb hush integrity and delivers fast and consistent mash tun drainage. This malt variety is perfect for brewing up a clear, bright pint.
Imparts a corn or grain taste. Mash required. Used to increase gravity of American lagers.
Can be used to lighten flavor and body when substituted for malt. Generally limit to 30% when used as an adjunct. Pasturize and add to primary during fermentation. Use up to 100% for meads.
Intensely sweet - adds a sweet malty flavor sometimes associated with honey. Also called Brumalt.
Nutty honey flavor. For brown ales, Belgian wheats, bocks and many other styles.
Used to increase starting gravity and also as an adjunct for some Belgian and English ales.
Very light lager malt used to make Pilsners, Lagers and other light beers. May be used as a base malt.
Pale dry malt extract for general purpose use. Use as base or to increase gravity of any full bodied ale or lager.
Liquid Invert Sugar. Used to increase alcohol and lighten the beer without alterning flavor. Used in Belgian ales and some English ales.
If added during the boil it will add a dry, woodsy flavor. If added at bottling, the smooth maple flavor comes through. Used for maple ales, porters, browns.

An English thoroughbred and a favored choice of malt for many brewers. Simpsons' Maris Otter has a rich and nutty flavor and despite its small, berry size has a strong husk. This malt delivers predictable brewhouse performance with modest, yet consistent extracts. Brewers can expect good runoffs with clear wort.
Aromatic malt from Banberg, Germany. Promotes a full flavor and rounds off beer color. Promotes deep red color and malty flavor.
Red Ales
Light flavor and creamy head. For American weizenbier, weissbier and dunkelweiss.
Also called "English Mild" - a light specialty malt used in Brown Ales
Not fully fermentable, so it adds lasting sweetness. Lactose can be added to lend sweetness to Sweet Stouts and Porters.
Imparts a strong, sweet flavor. Used primarily in stouts and porters.
Suitable for ales or lagers. It can be used with a single temperature infusion mash schedule.
Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a reddish amber color to the beer. Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention. Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers
Sweet, toasted flavor and aroma. For Oktoberfests and malty styles
Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a slight orange color to the beer. Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention. Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers
Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a orange to deep orange color to the beer. Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention. Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers
Adds body, mouth feel and head retention to the beer Used in oatmeal stouts and porters Adds substantial protein haze to light beers Protein rest recommended unless flakes are pregelatinized
Malted oats. Adds body, mouth feel and head retention to the beer Creates chill haze in lighter beers, so is primarily used in dark ones.
Unhopped pale liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any ale or lager.
Base malt for all beer styles Higher potential yield than US, English equivalent pale ale malts
Base malt for all English beer styles Lower diastatic power than American 2 Row Pale Malt
Base malt for all beer styles
Base malt for all beer styles
Premium base malt from the UK. Popular for many English styles of beer including ales, pale ales and bitters.
Robust smoky malt that provides a smoky flavor. Used in scottish ales and wee heavy ales.
Imparts a robust smokey flavor and aroma. Use in Scottish ales and Wee Heavies.
Belgian base malt for Continental lagers
German base for Pilsners and Bohemian Lagers
Pilsner base malt
Unhopped pale liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any ale or lager.

Used like other rice adjuncts in American and Japenes lagers to provide a dry, clean taste and light body. Adds gravity without changing body or flavor substantially. Use in place of corn sugar in small quantities.

Hulls are introduced to improve the speed of lautering when making high gravity or high adjunct beers. Hulls are neutral in flavor, body and color, and are inert Good for wheat beers, Wits, and others that have high protein mashes.
Used to add fermentables without increasing body or flavor. Produces a milder, less grainy tasting beer. Examples: American lagers, Bohemian lagers, Pilsners

Roasted at high temperature to create a burnt, grainy, coffee like flavor. Imparts a red to deep brown color to beer, and very strong roasted flavor. Use 2-4% in Brown ales to add a nutty flavor, or 3-10% in Porters and Stouts for coffee flavor.
Sweet, grainy, coffee flavor and a red to deep brown color. For porters and stouts.
Adds a dry, crisp character to the beer. Yields a deep red color, and a distinctive rye flavor Must limit to 10-15% fo the mash as it tends to produce "stuck" mashes.
Often used in German Ales and specialty beers
Imparts a dry, crisp rye flavor to rye beers. Can be easier to mash than raw rye.
Malt that has been smoked over an open fire. Creates a distinctive "smoked" flavor and aroma. Used primarily for German Rauchbier but can also be added to Brown Ales and Porters.
Extreme caramel aroma and flavored malt. Used in dark Belgian Abbey and Trappist ales. Unique flavor and aroma.
Use for English ales, nut brown ales and porters. Adds a toasted, biscuit like flavor and aroma

Excellent for Nut Brown Ales, Porter and other dark beer styles. Special processing develops unique Toasty, Biscuity, Sour, Tangy flavors distinctive to Special Roast Malt. Produced from AMBA/BMBRI recommended 6-Row Malting Barley varieties.
White table sugar, or sucrose primarily is used to increase alcohol. Using too much will add a cider flavor to beer.

Toasted malt can be made at home by toasting pale malted barley for 10-15 minutes at 350 F. Similar to Biscuit or Victory malt - this malt adds reddish/orange color and improved body without sweetness. Toasted flavor. Mashing required to avoid haze.
Imparts nutty flavor and aroma. Use in IPAs and Scottish ales.

UK mixture of molasses, invert sugar and golden (corn) syrup. Imparts an intense sweet flavor and dark color. Used in dark English ales. Also called "Black Treacle" or the brand name "Lyle's Black Treacle Syrup."
Light, raw brown sugar. May be used in British pale ales or high gravity Belgian ales. Limit percentage used to avoid undesirable flavors. Similar to Demerara sugar.
Toasted malt that adds a "Biscuit" or toasted flavor to English ales. Use for: Nut brown ales, porters
Kiln dried malt darker than Pale Malt, but not as dark as Munich Malt Imparts a golden to orange color to the beer.
Bock Beer, Dunkel Ale, Brown Ale , Red Lager, Amber Ale, Amber Lager
Amber Ale, Dunkel Lager, Dark Ale, Stout, Porter, Bock Beer
Gives deep aroma and color to dark beers, bocks, stout, alt and schwarzbier.
Carafa I, II and III also are available de-husked. Adds aroma, color and body.
Carafa I, II and III also are available de-husked. Adds aroma, color and body.
Pilsner, Lagerbier, alcohol-reduced Beer, Light Beer, Bock Beer
Hefe-Weizen, Pale Ale, Golden Ale, Oktoberfest Beer, Nourishing Beer, Maibock , Schankbier, Light Beer, alcohol-reduced Beer , non-alcoholic Beer
Provides body. For Oktoberfest, bock, porter, stout, red, amber and brown ales.
Provides body. For Oktoberfest, bock, porter, stout, red, amber and brown ales.
Provides body. For Oktoberfest, bock, porter, stout, red, amber and brown ales.
Red Ale, Red Lager, Scottish Ale, Amber Wheat, Bock Beer, Brown Ale, Alt Beer
Wheat based dry extract for use in all wheat beers. Use as base or to increase gravity of any wheat beer. Examples: Weizen, weiss, wheat ales and lagers
Unhopped Wheat liquid malt extract. Contains approx 60% Wheat, 40% Barley Use for Bavarian wheats, weizens, weiss and dunkel weizen styles.
Malted wheat for use in Wheat beers
Dark malted wheat base for use in dark wheat styles such as Dunkleweizen.
Malted wheat base for use in all wheat styles

Flaked wheat adds to increased body and foam retention Used in place of raw or torrified wheat for faster conversion and better yield. May be used in small amounts to improve head retention and body Examples: Belgian White beer, Wit

Also called Chocolate Wheat Malt. Kilned raw wheat - adds a deep, dark brown color to dunkelweizens and other dark beer styles. Roasted, woody, charcoal or burnt toast flavor depending on degree of roasting.

Unmodified wheat that has been "popped" to open the kernels Used primarily in place of raw wheat when making Belgian White and Wit Faster conversion and higher yield than raw wheat Protein rest recommended when mashing
White wheat gives a malty flavor not available from raw wheat. Used in Weiss, Wit and White beers
Weizens. Improves head retention in all beers. Contributes spicy flavor. Protein rest required.
